title: Samsung buoyed by Trump’s clampdown on Huawei
text:
US sanctions against Chinese giant Huawei helped prop up Samsung over the summer, analysts said, after the South Korean company’s profits dropped less than feared.

Samsung reported sales of around 62 trillion Korean won (£42bn) for the three months to the end of September, down around 5pc year on year.

Its operating profit for the period slipped further, hitting 7.7 trillion Korean won, 56pc lower than the same period a year earlier.

However, the figures were stronger than analysts had been expecting – profit had been forecast to come in at 6.9 trillion Korean won – causing shares to tick higher. Experts had thought Samsung would take a heavier hit from the ongoing slump in demand for memory chips, which account for around two thirds of the company's profits.

Park Sung-soon, an analyst at Cape Investment & Securities, said a wider industry slowdown had stemmed from “datacentre customers, a major driver for the memory chip business, pursuing conservative investment for the time being”.

Trade tensions are also keeping demand subdued, as companies voice concern over what new tariffs would mean for supply chains and for consumer appetite for new devices.

However there have been indications that the industry is nearing the bottom of the cycle, with the boss of Micron, a specialist in memory chips, last month saying he was “encouraged by signs of improving industry demand”.
description: US sanctions against Chinese giant Huawei helped prop up Samsung over the summer, analysts said, after the South Korean company’s profits dropped less than feared.
